early.description: Born on a bustling space station, your early life was filled with the hum of machinery and the vastness of space outside.
At age eight, you assisted in minor technical tasks, showcasing your aptitude for problem-solving.
You learned to navigate the station's complex corridors, honing your spatial awareness.
An encounter with a malfunctioning system taught you the importance of caution and technical knowledge.
You developed a knack for repairing equipment, demonstrating your resourcefulness.
Witnessing a minor accident instilled in you a deep understanding of the station's vulnerabilities.
You customized a tool kit from scavenged parts, improving your efficiency.
An engineer took you under their wing, teaching you advanced technical skills.
You formed a bond with another young resident, sharing knowledge and aspirations.
A close call with a decompression incident sharpened your instincts and reflexes.
You began studying engineering manuals, expanding your understanding of the station's systems.
An illness due to life support fluctuations tested your resilience and adaptability.
You discovered a hidden area of the station, fueling your curiosity.
A family member was reassigned, prompting you to become more independent.
You started experimenting with zero-gravity mechanics, enhancing your skills.
An encounter with corporate officials sparked your skepticism of authority.
You developed physical strength through maintenance work in challenging conditions.

mid.description: You took on significant responsibilities, managing critical systems aboard the station.
A conflict with corporate management led to increased tension and scrutiny.
You orchestrated a successful effort to upgrade essential systems.
An offer to transfer to another station challenged your loyalties.
You began mentoring newcomers, passing on your expertise.
A personal injury forced you to adapt, relying more on intellect than physical strength.
You discovered evidence of corporate negligence threatening the station.
A family member was unjustly reprimanded, fueling your desire for justice.
You faced ethical dilemmas when asked to overlook safety protocols.
An accident led to the loss of vital supplies, testing your resourcefulness.

late.description: A catastrophic event, such as a reactor failure, struck the station, and you played a key role in the initial response.
You navigated through collapsing sections to reach survivors, showcasing courage and agility.
Faced with limited resources, you had to make tough decisions to prioritize repairs.
You coordinated with others to send a distress signal, demonstrating leadership.
An opportunity to escape arose, but only a few could go; you had to decide who.
You exposed corporate negligence as the cause of the disaster, seeking accountability.
A personal tragedy during the disaster prompted deep reflection on your life's purpose.
You began to suffer from the psychological effects of the catastrophe.
A movement to rebuild or salvage what remained gained momentum, and you had to decide your role.
You mentored other survivors, helping them cope and plan for the future.
Conditions worsened, making survival increasingly challenging.
You authored a report documenting the disaster and lessons learned.
An external threat, such as approaching debris, endangered your group.
You faced a critical decision when offered a chance to leave with a rescue team.
An unexpected alliance offered new possibilities for survival but also new risks.
You considered the legacy you would leave and how to prevent future disasters.
A technological advancement provided hope for rescue or recovery, challenging you to adapt.
